data.title: Return Stars by Stanislaw Lem, First Edition
data.meta_description: Return from the Stars by LEM, STANISLAW Translated by Barbara Marszal & Frank Simpson. and a great selection of related books, art and collectibles available now at AbeBooks.com.
data.text:
Soft cover. Condition: Very Good -. Painted Front Cover. (illustrator). First Edition By This Publisher. 247 pages." Synopsis: Beyond future shock. Space wasn't half so scary, half so strange, or even half so alien, as what Hal Bregg returned to. He had been away from Planet Earth for ten years space-time. But that was 127 years back home and a lot of things had changed. Sex. Money. Transit. Violence. There's no more violence. Everyone gets it 'betrizated' out of them in childhood. .">> Cover creasing.; cover scuffing. Size: 12mo - over 6¾" - 7¾" Tall. Book.

Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Fine. 1st Edition. First US edition in beautiful condition. Book is clean bright and tight and sits square. Black boards with purple cloth spine with gilt lettering. Previous owners name on fly page, otherwise no other marks or inscriptions. UNclipped dust jacket in fine condition as has been in plastic protective archival sleeve since new. Please examine all photos. More available upon request.

Hardcover first edition - First US printing. This story of an astronaut who returns to earth after a 10 year mission during which 127 years had passed on earth to find a world totally alien to him - and with values opposite of those he had been taught as an astronaut - is one of Lem's most 'human' and appealing books. Originally published in 1961, and just now translated into English by Barbara Marszal and Frank Simpson. Good in good dust jacket (bump to upper edge of back cover, remainder line, creasing and tears to bottom edge of front cover of dj.).

Hardcover first edition - First US printing. This story of an astronaut who returns to earth after a 10 year mission during which 127 years had passed on earth to find a world totally alien to him - and with values opposite of those he had been taught as an astronaut - is one of Lem's most 'human' and appealing books. Originally published in 1961, and just now translated into English by Barbara Marszal and Frank Simpson. 247 pp. Very good in very good dust jacket (remainder line, chip to upper edge of back cover of dj).

Hardcover first edition - First US printing. This story of an astronaut who returns to earth after a 10 year mission during which 127 years had passed on earth to find a world totally alien to him - and with values opposite of those he had been taught as an astronaut - is one of Lem's most 'human' and appealing books. Originally published in 1961, and just now translated into English by Barbara Marszal and Frank Simpson. 247 pp. Fine in very good dust jacket (crease to front flap of dj, short closed tear to front cover).

Hardcover first edition - First US printing. This story of an astronaut who returns to earth after a 10 year mission during which 127 years had passed on earth to find a world totally alien to him - and with values opposite of those he had been taught as an astronaut - is one of Lem's most 'human' and appealing books. Originally published in 1961, and just now translated into English by Barbara Marszal and Frank Simpson. 247 pp. Fine in fine dust jacket.

Octavo, cloth-backed boards. First U.S. edition. "Shows Earth with highly developed technology, a world where all work is performed by robots." - Dunn and Erlich (editors), The Mechanical God, p. 246. "Return from the Stars is one of Lem's several works focusing on utopia. Out of those, it is the least pessimistic about the consequences of technological progress and their effect on our sociocultural evolution. Even so, the depicted world is not perfect: in a pacified society, with no conflict, stress, and danger, Lem argues that humans will become unable to take any risks, to take initiative, commit themselves to any serious tasks, and even lose the ability for self-assertion and for feeling strong emotions. Return from the Stars asks whether some sociocultural advances, like peace, are worth the price we may pay for losing part of our nature" (Wikipedia). A translation of POWRÓT Z GWIAZD (1961). A fine copy in fine dust jacket priced $8.95 on the front flap. (#173578).
